dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, really? Is International Safe Abortion Day actually something we should be talking about, like, with everything else going on?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, really? Is International Safe Abortion Day actually something we should be talking about, like, with everything else going on?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah, it totally is. I mean, September 28th, it's about remembering, um, women who've died because of, you know, these really oppressive laws.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah, it totally is. I mean, September twenty eighth, it's about remembering, um, women who've died because of, you know, these really oppressive laws.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On September 28, activists around the world will mark International Safe Abortion Day, an opportunity to mourn those who have died because of oppressive anti-abortion laws.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but 'oppressive laws'? Isn't it just a political football in a few places?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but 'oppressive laws'? Isn't it just a political football in a few places?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's the thing, though. The article says it's, like, a fact of life. Twenty-five percent of all pregnancies, uh, fifty-six million, are terminated each year. That's huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the thing, though. The article says it's, like, a fact of life. Twenty-five percent of all pregnancies, uh, fifty-six million, are terminated each year. That's huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Each year, 25% of all pregnancies about 56 million are terminated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but that's mostly, like, in certain countries, isn't it? Developing nations, uh, less educated areas or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but that's mostly, like, in certain countries, isn't it? Developing nations, uh, less educated areas or something?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Actually, no. It happens everywhere, every socioeconomic class. In the US, almost two-thirds of patients identify with an organized religion. But yes, eighty-eight percent are in the Global South, where access to, like, family planning is super limited.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, no. It happens everywhere, every socioeconomic class. In the U S, almost two-thirds of patients identify with an organized religion. But yes, eighty-eight percent are in the Global South, where access to, like, family planning is super limited.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Abortions occur in every country and within every socioeconomic class. In the United States, ... nearly two-thirds identify with an organized religion. ... In fact, a staggering 88% of the worlds abortions occur in the Global South.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Still, if it's, you know, illegal, then people shouldn't be doing it anyway, should they? No one's forcing them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, if it's, you know, illegal, then people shouldn't be doing it anyway, should they? No one's forcing them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But that's where it gets dangerous. It doesn't stop abortions, it just makes them unsafe. Sixty thousand maternal deaths a year from complications. Seven million hospitalizations. It's, like, a medical crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But that's where it gets dangerous. It doesn't stop abortions, it just makes them unsafe. Sixty thousand maternal deaths a year from complications. Seven million hospitalizations. It's, like, a medical crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...complications from risky procedures...lead to some seven million hospitalizations and kill 47,000 women every year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. I always thought it was, like, a modern thing, pushed by, uh, feminists or whatever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. I always thought it was, like, a modern thing, pushed by, uh, feminists or whatever.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's centuries old! Ancient China, Egypt, Rome â€“ it was normal. It was only, um, in the nineteenth century that Catholic and colonial elites made it illegal, to control women, basically.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's centuries old! Ancient China, Egypt, Rome - it was normal. It was only, um, in the nineteenth century that Catholic and colonial elites made it illegal, to control women, basically.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the methods varied, abortion was a normal and often accepted practice in ancient China, Egypt, Greece, and Rome. It was only in the nineteenth century that Catholic and colonial elites propagated anti-abortion laws to control womens sexuality, bodies, and lives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what, it's just about, like, numbers then? More women dying in places it's banned?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what, it's just about, like, numbers then? More women dying in places it's banned?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! When it's decriminalized, deaths plummet. Romania, South Africa... they saw massive drops. It's not, like, some theoretical benefit; it's proven.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! When it's decriminalized, deaths plummet. Romania, South Africa... they saw massive drops. It's not, like, some theoretical benefit; it's proven.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, a year after Romania decriminalized abortion in 1990, maternal deaths fell by half, while in South Africa, deaths plummeted 91% in the first four years after passage of the 1996 Choice on Termination of Pregnancy Act.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, uh, what's this about doctors denying service? Like, based on personal beliefs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, uh, what's this about doctors denying service? Like, based on personal beliefs?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's happening in, um, over seventy jurisdictions globally, forty-five US states. That directly leads to more dangerous, clandestine abortions. It's unconscionable, frankly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's happening in, um, over seventy jurisdictions globally, forty-five U S states. That directly leads to more dangerous, clandestine abortions. It's unconscionable, frankly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recent research conducted by my organization, the International Womens Health Coalition, found that in more than 70 jurisdictions worldwide including 45 US states health-care providers can deny abortion services to patients based simply on doctors personal beliefs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, it's not going away? This isn't just a niche issue?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, it's not going away? This isn't just a niche issue?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No way! The fight's far from over. Women everywhere are demanding reproductive justice. We have to, um, guarantee a woman's right to this care. Elizabeth's story is just one of millions, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No way! The fight's far from over. Women everywhere are demanding reproductive justice. We have to, um, guarantee a woman's right to this care. Elizabeth's story is just one of millions, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unless things change, honestly, every single one of them is a potential tragedy. It's, um, it's really that serious.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unless things change, honestly, every single one of them is a potential tragedy. It's, um, it's really that serious.
